pitrou commented on pull request #11477:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11477#issuecomment-956322729


   Why was this done? If you're using the conda package, you shouldn't use the bundled version, and vice-versa.


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

lidavidm commented on pull request #11477:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11477#issuecomment-956329198


   IIRC the issue was: we required GTest 1.11, but still installed 1.10 via Conda, and in the end we would use the headers from 1.10 but link to 1.11, because the `-I` directive for the Conda prefix's `include` dir came first. There's a longer discussion on Zulip.


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

To unsubscribe, e-mail: github-unsubscribe@arrow.apache.org

For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on pull request #11477:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11477#issuecomment-956330196


   ARROW_GTEST_BUILD_VERSION is not the required version, it's only the version used when building a bundled version. It shouldn't conflict with the conda-installed version.


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

pitrou commented on pull request #11477:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11477#issuecomment-956330779


   However, it's an error to both install it with Conda _and_ ask CMake to build a bundled version. I have no clue where this happens, because the release script is a mess.


--

lidavidm commented on pull request #11477:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11477#issuecomment-956331586


   Ah, sorry, I misunderstood then - but regardless, the failing builds were building GTest from source, so we still had the version mismatch.
   
   The Zulip discussion starts [here](https://ursalabs.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/180245-dev/topic/6.2E0.2E0.20release.20timing/near/258354489)
   
   The better fix would probably have been to prioritize the bundled include directory over the Conda one.


--

   Ah, sorry, I misunderstood then - but regardless, the failing builds were building GTest from source, so we still had the version mismatch.
   
   The Zulip discussion starts ~[here](https://ursalabs.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/180245-dev/topic/6.2E0.2E0.20release.20timing/near/258354489)~ sorry, [here](https://ursalabs.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/180245-dev/topic/6.2E0.2E0.20release.20timing/near/258348836) is the full thread

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.summary: [C++] GTest linking errors during the source release verification

comments.body:
Failing on MSVC 19.16.27045.0: https://github.com/ursacomputing/crossbow/runs/3949371326?check_suite_focus=true#step:6:577
Passing on MSVC 19.29.30136.0 https://github.com/apache/arrow/runs/3941383442#step:7:51

Probably should pin an earlier gtest version https://github.com/google/googletest/issues/3578
Same error occurs in the nightly vcpkg built https://github.com/ursacomputing/crossbow/runs/3947956904#step:4:2718 which uses the same windows-2019 GHA instance where we have the passing build.
